meta.description:
Label Generation Rules for Danish

Overview

This document specifies a reference set of Label Generation Rules for Danish using a limited repertoire as appropriate for a second level domain.

Repertoire

Most references converge on 31 (29+2) Latin code points. In addition to the 29 letters of the alphabet proper, these include two letter used as part of the proper spelling of certain words: U+00E9 LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH ACUTE and U+00FC LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH DIAERESIS. Both occur in spelling dictionaries and especially the former is used in many ordinary words. The repertoire here adds U+00E4 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH DIAERESIS and U+00F6 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH DIAERESIS, both of which are used in neighboring Sweden and Germany. Finally, the use of all three code points with diaresis, alone or together with code points from the core Danish alphabet such as U+00F8 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH STROKE is not uncommon in family names. All three are available on Danish keyboards.

There is no IDN table published in the IANA Repository of IDN Practices by .dk ccTLD, but the registry provides IDN information [700].

Excluded code points

Letters documented in some references but not included:

  • U+00E0 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH GRAVE

  • U+00E1 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH ACUTE

  • U+00E2 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH CIRCUMFLEX

  • U+01FB LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH RING ABOVE AND ACUTE

  • U+00E7 LATIN SMALL LETTER C WITH CEDILLA

  • U+00E8 LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH GRAVE

  • U+00EA LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH CIRCUMFLEX

  • U+00EB LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH DIAERESIS

  • U+00ED LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH ACUTE

  • U+00EE LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH CIRCUMFLEX

  • U+00EF LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH DIAERESIS

  • U+00F0 LATIN SMALL LETTER ETH

  • U+00F1 LATIN SMALL LETTER N WITH TILDE

  • U+00F3 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH ACUTE

  • U+00F4 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH CIRCUMFLEX

  • U+00F9 LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH GRAVE

  • U+00FA LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH ACUTE

  • U+00FB LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH CIRCUMFLEX

  • U+00FD LATIN SMALL LETTER Y WITH ACUTE

  • U+00FE LATIN SMALL LETTER THORN

  • U+00FF LATIN SMALL LETTER Y WITH DIAERESIS

  • U+0153 LATIN SMALL LIGATURE OE

  • U+01FD LATIN SMALL LETTER AE WITH ACUTE

  • U+01FF LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH STROKE AND ACUTE

The above list includes code points for languages like Faroese, which are written in territories associated with the country of Denmark, but that are not part of the Danish language.

Extended code points

None.

Variants

None.

Character Classes

This LGR defines no named character classes.

Rules

Common rules only:

  • Hyphen Restrictions — restrictions on the allowable placement of hyphens (no leading/ending hyphen and no hyphen in positions 3 and 4). These restrictions are described in section 4.2.3.1 of RFC5891 [120]. They are implemented here as context rule on U+002D (-) HYPHEN-MINUS.

  • Leading Combining Marks — restrictions on the allowable placement of combining marks (no leading combining mark). This rule is described in section 4.2.3.2 of RFC5891 [120].

Actions

Actions included are the default actions for LGRs as well as those needed to invalidate labels with misplaced combining marks.

Methodology and Contributors

This reference LGR for Danish for the 2nd Level has been developed by Michel Suignard and Asmus Freytag, verified in expert reviews by Michael Everson, Nicholas Ostler, and Wil Tan, and based on multiple open public consultations.

References

General references for the language:

  • Dansk sprognævn. 1996. Retskrivningsordbogen. 2. udgave. København: Aschehoug. ISBN 87-11-10000-1

  • Dansk sprognævn, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

  • Wikipedia: "Danish orthography", http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danish_alphabet

  • Sproget.dk, published in Danish as a co-operation between Kulturministeriets institutioner for sprog og litteratur, Dansk Sprognævn (DSN) and Det Danske Sprog- og Litteraturselskab (DSL). Section under "Råd og regler", "Retskrivningsregler", "Bogstaverne", http://sproget.dk/raad-og-regler/retskrivningsregler/retskrivningsregler/a7-1-6/a7-1-bogstaverne

  • Københavns Universitet. Afdeling for Navneforskning, "Navneforskning" (Department for Name Research, Copenagen University) http://danskernesnavne.navneforskning.ku.dk accessed 2015-11-24

  • Omniglot: Danish (dansk) http://www.omniglot.com/writing/danish.htm

In the listing of the repertoire by code point, references starting from [0] refer to the version of the Unicode Standard in which the corresponding code point was initially encoded. Other references (starting from [100]) document usage of code points. For more details, see the Table of References below.

reference.comment: Code points cited were originally encoded in Unicode Version 1.1

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium. The Unicode Standard, Version 6.3.0, ( Mountain View, CA: The Unicode Consortium, 2013. ISBN 978-1-936213-08-5) http://www.unicode.org/versions/Unicode6.3.0/
Internetstiftelsen i Sverige (IIS), "IDN Reference table for Danish language" https://github.com/dotse/IDN-ref-tables/blob/master/language-tables/danish-lang-ref-table.txt
RFC5891, Internationalized Domain Names in Applications (IDNA): Protocol http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5891

reference.comment: This table lists only the characters outside the set a-z

references.reference: ISO/IEC 6937 Third Ed. 2001-12-17- Information technology — Coded graphic character set for text communication — Latin alphabet: Table D.1 (p 35) Use of Latin alphabetic characters.

reference.comment: Code points cited form the standard set

references.reference: Everson, Michael. The Alphabets of Europe: "Danish" http://www.evertype.com/alphabets/danish.pdf

reference.comment: Code points cited are from an extended set

references.reference: Everson, Michael. The Alphabets of Europe: "Danish" http://www.evertype.com/alphabets/danish.pdf

reference.comment: Code points cited are rare or archaic

references.reference: Everson, Michael. The Alphabets of Europe: "Danish" http://www.evertype.com/alphabets/danish.pdf

reference.comment: Code points cited are from the set of Main Letters

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium, Common Locale Data Repository (CLDR) Version 28 (2015-09-16) - Locale Data Summary for Danish [da] http://www.unicode.org/cldr/charts/28/summary/da.html

reference.comment: Code points cited are from the Auxiliary set

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium, Common Locale Data Repository (CLDR) Version 28 (2015-09-16) - Locale Data Summary for Danish [da] http://www.unicode.org/cldr/charts/28/summary/da.html

reference.comment: Code points cited are of category 1: Letters essential for the language

references.reference: Dansk sprognævn, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

reference.comment: Code points cited are of category 2: Letters commonly used, but not essential

references.reference: Dansk sprognævn, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

reference.comment: Code points cited are of category 3: Letters used for names, in common practice

references.reference: Dansk sprognævn, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

reference.comment: Code points cited are of category 4: Letters that are rarely used

references.reference: Dansk sprognævn, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

reference.comment: According to this reference, the alphabet is listed as using the full basic set A-Z
Code points cited are supported in a national edition of ISO-646.

references.reference: ISO/IEC 646:1991 — Information technology — ISO 7-bit coded character set for information interchange

reference.comment: The table only lists code points beyond A-Z
Code points cited are the non-ASCII code points listed by the registry for .dk domain

char.comment: LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH DIAERESIS
LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH RING ABOVE
LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH ACUTE
LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH DIAERESIS
LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH STROKE
LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH DIAERESIS

rule.name: leading-combining-mark
rule.comment: RFC5891 restrictions on placement of combining marks

rule.name: hyphen-minus-disallowed
rule.comment: RFC5891 restrictions on placement of U+002D
no consecutive hyphens in third and fourth

rule.name: extended-cp
rule.comment: code points from the extended range

action.comment: by default, labels with leading combining marks are invalid
